title: Extended diagnostics should link to angular.io documentation

labels.name: feature
labels.description: Issue that requests a new feature

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/releated to the feature request?

compiler-cli

### Description

Extended diagnostics have fairly comprehensive documentation on https://angular.io/extended-diagnostics/, with a page for each error code. These include explanations of exactly why the pattern is bad, what users can do about it, and how to suppress it if necessary. Currently however, users get only an error message in their console / IDE. This is hopefully expressive enough for many users, but it is not as comprehensive as AIO, and we should be pointing users to that documentation if they have any questions.

### Proposed solution

Extended diagnostics should include a link to their AIO page. Ideally, this is something they can do automatically in a common format so future diagnostics implicitly get this link and incentivize the team to continue to write comprehensive documentation about these checks.

### Alternatives considered

N/A

title: documentation: wrong baseHref syntax in angular.json snippet

labels.name: comp: docs
labels.description: Anything related to doc content, incl guides, API reference, tutorial, web content

labels.description: An issue that it suitable for a community contributor (based on its complexity/scope).

labels.description: Medium priority issue that needs to be resolved

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Milestone for triaged issues that have not yet been scheduled for resolution.

body:
### Description

In the [Deploy multiple locales](https://angular.io/guide/i18n-common-deploy) page the first json snippet has an incorrect syntax.

Current incorrect syntax:
```json
"locales": {
  "fr": "src/locale/messages.fr.xlf",
  "baseHref": ""
}
```

Correct syntax:
```json
"locales": {
  "fr": {
      "translation":"src/locale/messages.fr.xlf",
      "baseHref": ""
   }
}
```

I believe the issue had been fixed in the past when the snippets were directly in the *.md files : https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/38553#pullrequestreview-472935025.
 but the error is still here in the file [i18n/angular.json](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/aio/content/examples/i18n/angular.json).

The part we want to change in this file is referenced in two places with the regions *locale-config* and *i18n-baseHref*.
To fix it for the region *i18n-baseHref* and keep it the same way for the region *locale-config* we might need to do something like duplicating the *locales* node or do a new file for *i18n-baseHref*.

Unfortunately I can't do the PR myself because I have some errors during the installation of this repository which prevent me to check how the modifications to the json would impact the final documentation.


### What is the affected URL?

https://angular.io/guide/i18n-common-deploy

### Please provide the steps to reproduce the issue

documentation issue

### Please provide the expected behavior vs the actual behavior you encountered

Current incorrect syntax:
```json
"locales": {
  "fr": "src/locale/messages.fr.xlf",
  "baseHref": ""
}
```

Correct syntax:
```json
"locales": {
  "fr": {
      "translation":"src/locale/messages.fr.xlf",
      "baseHref": ""
   }
}
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7252481/153284788-715e5c22-c777-4fb1-9368-66e26e5f750b.png)

```true
In the [Deploy multiple locales](https://angular.io/guide/i18n-common-deploy) page the first json snippet has an incorrect syntax.
```

```true
no
```

title: Providing DOCUMENT in a unit test affects underlying TestBedRender

labels.name: comp: core
labels.description: Runtime issues

milestone.title: needsTriage
milestone.description: Milestone for all issues that haven't been triaged yet

body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

We're using the [DOCUMENT](https://angular.io/api/common/DOCUMENT) injection token and attempted to provide a mock implementation for a unit test.  Doing so appears to interfere with the underlying test framework, such as in `destroyAfterEach` when it attempts to use the mocked provider instead of the actual document to call `querySelectorAll`.

It seems like for internal TestBed functionality, it shouldn't rely on the `providers` configured for the testing module.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-gvyjdz?file=src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.spec.ts

```true
    at Function.createComponent (https://angular-ivy-gvyjdz.stackblitz.io/turbo_modules/@angular/core@13.2.2/fesm2015/testing.mjs:1622:37)

```

### Anything else?

As a workaround, if it were a Component unit test, we could `.overrideComponent()` and add a provider to get around it, but in our case the unit test is for an `@Injectable` service, and it's less straightforward to override a provider for a service.

body:
Returning `UrlTree` from a guard was a convenient new feature added to
the `Router`. However, it does not have feature-parity with the old
`router.navigate(...); return false;` pattern. The most common use-case
for this feature is to redirect to a new page _without_ updating the URL
from the initially attempted navigation. For example, rendering a 404
page when the user does not have access privelages to a route.

Fixes #17004
Fixes #27148

body:
## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [ ] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [x] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:

## What is the new behavior?

Added a target for the aio project to be built by bazel. It does not yet include the generated content and is not used by the ci.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No


<!-- If this PR contains a breaking change, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications below. -->


## Other information

Since architect requires the generated ngsw-config.json to be in the source root, I added a rule that will write to it and ensure it exists and is up to date (see [write_source_files](https://docs.aspect.build/aspect-build/bazel-lib/v0.4.3/docs/docs/write_source_files-docgen.html)). I chose to commit that file here, and that will be required once aio is fully built with bazel, but if you prefer I can leave it uncommitted for now---running the bazel build on aio will just pop out an error with a command to generate it.

Another decision I made was to move the ngsw-config.json out of `src/generated` to the root. This is because on each regular build the `generated` folder is deleted, and since I would need a `BUILD.bazel` file in there to stamp the `write_source_files`, it would be deleted and someone developing using the regular build would see the file missing in their git diff. Another option I could do is to make that deletion script a bit more picky about what it deletes.

Overall this is a first partial step in the migration.

title: zone.js cause "Unable to preventDefault inside passive event listener invocation." "errors", if passive handler is added first

body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

Don't known / other

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

There is issue with zone.js **addEventListener** patch. If you add listener with { passive: true } options first, same handler will be used for non-passive event listeners. As result calling event.preventDefault() causing error. Code example:

```
import 'zone.js';

document.addEventListener('mousemove', (ev) => {}, { passive: true });
document.addEventListener('mousemove', (ev) => {
  ev.preventDefault(); // throws error
});
```

title: Custom validators on blur, not ran when blurring without value change

milestone.title: needsTriage
milestone.description: Milestone for all issues that haven't been triaged yet

body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

forms

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

It seems that custom validators do not run on blur when value is not changed. Which results in unwanted behavior.

**AS-IS**
I have a formGroup with multiple required fields (default angular required validator) and with updateOn: 'blur'. 
On the formGroup i have 1 validator which checks if any one of the fields is touched and invalid, then an error message should be displayed.
When initially entering the page, all fields are invalid, but none of them are touched --> no error message
When i enter a value in the first field and blur --> first field is valid and touch, other invalid and untouched --> no error message
BUT when i enter the next field, and immediately tab to the next without entering a value, the field is touched and invalid --> but still no error message is shown.

**EXPECTED**
In the last use-case above, 
 when i enter the next field, and immediately tab to the next without entering a value --> I expect the field to be invalid and touched and run my custom validator which then result in the error being displayed.


**CAUSE**
it seems that custom validators are only being ran on actual value change, and not on the actual blur functionality.
Even when not changing values, but just blurring, i do want the custom validator to run.


**SOLUTION FOR MYSELF (NOT IDEAL)**
Currently i use the (blur) event on each field to update the value and validity of that field only when an empty field is blurred.
I attached a link to a stackblitz where you can play around with the code.
In here you can see by the console log, that the custom validator is not being ran when click in and out a field.
I commented out the fix, you can just uncomment these lines in the .ts and .html file, and then you have my current solution.


In my opinion this should not be the expected behavior of running these validators on blur.
Open for discussion :) 



### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-iznhmk?file=src/app/app.component.ts

_No response_

body:
some elements in the aio sidenav (especially anchors) are still
included in the tab order even though they are not visible, fix
such behavior by applying `display: none` to the closed sidenav
so that its elements become non-interactable

body:
currently if a user tries to navigate via keyboard, once the are
presented with search results, the search results panel remains
present and can potentially hide most of the content on the page,
in such case keyboard navigation will be severly hindered and
the only option for the user would be to go back to the seach input

body:
# 🐞 Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [x] build ### Is this a regression? Unknown. I am in the process of updating from Angular 10.x (where things build fine) to 13.x (where things are breaking), but it's unclear if this is a regression. ### Description I have two Angular library projects in a monorepo. Project B depends on Project A. Both are pretty small. When attempting to build both, Project A builds successfully but Project B fails with the following error: ``` Schema validation failed with the following errors: Data path "/error" must be string. ``` It's unclear what schema the error is referring to and it's also unclear what `Data path "/error"` is referring to. If "schema" refers to `angular.json` in this context, it's unclear what `Data path "/error"` is referring to since an "error" key isn't documented for `angular.json`. ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction Clone the [angular-cli-build-bug](https://gitlab.com/service-work/is-loading/-/tree/angular-cli-build-bug) branch of my `service-work/is-loading` repo. The repo contains a [`.devcontainer.json` file](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/remote/create-dev-container) which can be used to quickly setup the dev environment. 1. run `yarn install` 2. (optional) run `yarn test`. Tests should all pass. 3. run `yarn build`. The `@service-work/is-loading` project should build successfully but the `@service-work/scroll-position` library should fail with the following message: ``` Schema validation failed with the following errors: Data path "/error" must be string. ``` Note that the `@service-work/scroll-position` package depends on the `@service-work/is-loading` package. However, the only file in `@service-work/scroll-position` that actually imports from `@service-work/is-loading` is the `projects/scroll-position/src/scroll-position/module/directive/scroll-position.directive.ts` file. If you comment out the `@service-work/is-loading` import in that file, as well as the related code, then the `@service-work/scroll-position` file builds without error. It's unclear if there's something wrong in my code which is preventing the project from building (in which case the provided error message should be improved to make clear what the problem is) or if there's a bug with the build script. ## 🔥 Exception or Error 

Schema validation failed with the following errors:
  Data path "/error" must be string.

title: Custom form controls extending AbstractControl beyond the default ones

milestone.title: needsTriage
milestone.description: Milestone for all issues that haven't been triaged yet

body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/releated to the feature request?

forms

### Description

Lately I have been struggling with reusing form areas. I read all about CVA and sub forms with inputs etc... They seemed to miss something. At the beginning I was sure CVA would be the best fit which almost was the case. The problem started when I needed to render parts of the form in tabs yet all of them created together one form. For the sake of the explanation let's take a simple date range component as an example. The control has built in validation to make sure the `from` field isn't greater than the `to` field. At some point I loaded an invalid form (wrong date range) due to business requirements to the form yet the form was valid. The reason was the CVA component included the validation yet it wasn't rendered. That brought me to think the missing part was the decoupling of form logic from the UI. In regular reactive forms it works well - in the TS you add controls and validators and only bind it to the html which doesn't necessarily need to be rendered. In the CVA or sub forms "land" the form and UI is coupled together.
The feature request I thought is why not create a class called `DateRangeFormControl` extending `AbstractControl`. The whole form logic with validations will be there while the UI will be in the component.
This allows us a few benefits:
1. Decoupled logic and UI - will solve the CVA validation problem from above
2. Possible reusability with different components
3. Still easily apply through `formControlName` and use inside say a form group in the parent

### Proposed solution

Having the possibility to create custom form controls and restrict components to accept specific custom control types in `formControlName`/ `formControl` or something similar.
For example if it was implemented:
1. A component called `date-range.component.ts` exists.
2. Adding another file near it called `date-range.form.ts` which contains:
```ts
export class DateRangeFormControl extends AbstractContol {
  // Implements DateRange specific logic here - model + validation + maybe custom functions
}
```
3. `DateRangeComponent` would implement CVA (or another interface?) and declare it only accepts `DateRangeFormControl` somehow so it can safely use its functions and structure.
4. In the parent component the ts declaration will be:
```ts
form = new FormGroup({
  one: new FormControl('...'),
  two: new DateRangeFormControl({from: ..., to: ...})
})
```
5. In the parent HTML the declaration will be:
```html
<app-date-range formControlName/customFormControlName="two"></app-date-range>
```

There are still a few things which require more thought - How to restrict to certain controls in a component? Can we use the same form directives? Is CVA the correct interface here (as we want to decouple the form logic yet CVA requires functions like `setValue` to be implemented on the component)? Probably using form group inside the custom form component is required yet how to achieve it as it should act as a form control to the outside? And I believe many more... 

### Alternatives considered

1. Regular CVA while hiding with display none instead of ngif
2. Pass form as input from parent
3. Create form in child and add it with `ControlContainer` injection
4. Create form in child and add it through parent view child

All of the above suffer from drawbacks - the proposed solution seems to fix them all
